summary: A total 293 scats were analysed and Litter was found in 21 (7,2%), 9 (7%, n=129) scats where collected at the uplands and 12 (7,2%, n=164) at the Dehesa ecosystem.
reference: Fedriani, J.M. 1996. Dieta anual del zorro, Vulpes vulpes, en dos hábitats del Parque Nacional de Doñana. Acta Vertebrata, 23(2), 143-152

summary: A total of 65 stomachs investigated fron 1974 to 1981 and anthropogenic rubbish (some identify as cardboard) was found in afrequency of 1,37% in Autumn, 4,35% in Spring, and 7,5% in Summer. No anthropogenic rubbish was found in faecal analysis (n=120) collected between 1979 and 1981
reference: Venero, J.L. (1984). Dieta de los grandes fitófagos del Parque Nacional de Doñana. Acta Vertebrata, 11(3), 130

summary: A total of 74 stomachs were analized from 1976 to 1981. Two stomachs (6,67%) collected in Autumn contained plastic bags. Nine stomachs (28,13%) collected in winter contained plastic bags, while one stomach contained cigarrette bugs. Another stomach collected in Spring (10%F) contained plastic bags, but also a piece of a rope and socks were found. All stomachs collected in Summer (n=2) contained plastic bags. A total of 120 faecal samples were collected from October 1979 and July 1981 and anthropogenic items were found.
reference: Venero, J.L. (1984). Dieta de los grandes fitófagos del Parque Nacional de Doñana. Acta Vertebrata, 11(3), 130

summary: A total of 54 stomachs were analysed from 1976 to 1981. Only a piece of rope was found in one stomach (12,77%) collected in Summer. A total of 120 faecal samples were collected from October 1979 and July 1981 and anthropogenic items were found.
reference: Venero, J.L. (1984). Dieta de los grandes fitófagos del Parque Nacional de Doñana. Doñana Acta Vertebrata, 11(3), 130

summary: Garbage appeared in stomachs from 1965 with a 42,8%F and 5.3%Volume, and in 1966 with a 47,8%F and 11.8%volume. In general, Grabage was the forth most important item in terms of volume and eight in terms of frequency.
reference: Henry, V.G. & Conley, R.H. (1972). Fall Foods of European Wild Hogs in the Southern Appalachians. The Journal of Wildlife Management, 36(3), 854

summary: Garbage/Rubbish was found in 11 scats (48%F) and consitituted the 23.3% of the drymatter (n=25). Garbage included plastics, paper and ropes.

summary: Three killer whales presented anthropogenic items in their stomachs: U71/2299 (indeterminated year) contained a piece of string; a male of 6.10 m stranded 4th July 1969 (69/10) had a piece of dry suit, plastic milk bottle, plastic sheeting, cardboard carton (male 6,1m); and a male of 5.95 cm (91/17) contained a piece of rope and fishing line
reference: Best, P.B., Meÿer, M.A. & Lockyer, C. (2010). Killer whales in South African waters—a review of their biology. African Journal of Marine Science, 32(2), 171–186 &

summary: A total of 72.8% (SD=4.7) of mullet (n=51) contained plastic in their digestive tracts. An average of 3.2 particles per fish were found, with a total of 260 particles identified. Fibers comprised 51.2%, fragments 34,6%, polystyrene 7.3%, films 5.0%, 1.5% monofilament line and 0.4% twine.
reference: Naidoo, T., Smit, A. & Glassom, D. (2016). Plastic ingestion by estuarine mullet Mugil cephalus (Mugilidae) in an urban harbour, KwaZulu-Natal, South Africa. African Journal of Marine Science, 38(1), 145–149

Miscellaneous items where found, which included plastic bags, wire,
sand and stones in 21% (Table 1).

summary: A total of 20% of the refuse items (2.4%) was house garbage

summary: A total of 76 anthropogenic items (14.8%N, n=237) were recorded. They were classified in two groups: 1) remains from domestic animals (e.g. fish, claws, feathers bone chips and fish remains; 2) derived frome xplotable scraps (plastic bags, bottle tops and fragments of glass)
reference: Kaunda, S.K.K. & Skinner, J.D. 2003. Black-backed jackal diet at Mokolodi Nature Reserve, Botswana. African Journal of Ecology, 41(1), 39–46

summary:
A total of three scats contained anthropogenic items (plastic and metal) (0.4%F, n=295, Great Fish River
Reserve; 1.1%F, n=201, Kwandwe Private Game Reserve)
